title: Widows in Kenya fight to keep their homes | The World | ABC NEWS
description: In Kenya, women who have lost their husbands often face cultural pressure to give up their inheritance, which can lead to a cycle of poverty for widows and their children. Advocates are trying to change that, hoping to pass a bill that would provide legal aid to women fighting to keep their homes. Rebecca Johnston reports. title: Author threatens defamation action against SA premier | ABC NEWS
description: The South Australian premier has been threatened with defamation proceedings over comments he made about a writer whose appearance at Adelaide Writers‚Äô Week was cancelled. Peter Malinauskas says his remarks are on the public record and people will see that they're founded in a place of compassion.  The 2026 Writers' Week was cancelled after more than 180 authors and participants withdrew from the event. The Adelaide Festival Corporation has since apologised to author Randa Abdel-Fattah and says she will be invited to speak at its next event in 2027. description: A massive clean-up is underway after flash flooding along the Great Ocean Road in Victoria. title: Former South Korean President Yoon faces criminal sentencing over failed martial law | ABC NEWS
description: Supporters of Yoon Suk Yeol have gathered outside the central court in Seoul as former South Korean President faces his first criminal sentencing over charges relating to his failed martial law bid in 2024. Prosecutors are seeking the death penalty on the most serious charge. title: Trump given Nobel Peace medal by Venezuelan opposition leader Machado | ABC NEWS
description: Venezuela's opposition leader Mar√≠a Corina Machado says she has presented her Nobel Peace Prize to US President Donald Trump. She did not say whether Mr Trump accepted it.  The pair met in Washington on Thursday, local time, for lunch before Ms Machado left to meet senators at the Capitol.   As she left that second meeting, she was swarmed by media and said she had presented Mr Trump with the esteemed medal in "recognition for his unique commitment with our freedom".  Ms Machado then referenced the gifting of a medal by the revolutionary Marquis de Lafayette 200 years ago to South American revolutionary leader Sim√≥n Bol√≠va to signify the pair's shared values.  Ms Machado was awarded the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize in October for her "tireless work promoting democratic rights for the people of Venezuela and for her struggle to achieve a just and peaceful transition from dictatorship to democracy".   She fled Venezuela late last year and has been pressing the US to help advance a democratic transition after the capture of long-time Venezuelan President Nicol√°s Maduro. title: How unusual and significant was the storm event on Victoria's Surf Coast? | ABC NEWS
description: Alistair Drayton, the chief officer of operations at Victorian SES has praised the community as no injuries or missing persons were reported in the flash flooding event along the Great Ocean Road. The Bureau of Meteorology says more than 180mm of rain fell in about a 4-hour period, inundating areas around Wye River and Lorne, with dozens of cars and caravans swept out to sea. title: Taste testing Japan's free school meals | ABC NEWS
description: Japan's emphasis on good eating has long attracted favourable attention, especially when compared to the greasy canteen meals of the United States and the recent childcare food scandals in Australia.  Another source of envy is the fact child care in Japan is free for children over three years old.  Costs for younger kids are relative to income, meaning child care remains affordable to even the lowest-paid workers. title: 'Significant' theft of toxic poppies could cause death, Tasmanian authorities warn | ABC NEWS
description: Tasmania Police says poppy capsules, grown to produce medicinal opioids, have been taken in a "significant quantity" from a regulated crop between Tunbridge and Campbell Town in the Northern Midlands.  The Health Department advises poppy plants are toxic, ingestion can be life-threatening and should be treated as an emergency. title: Australian who escaped Iran's brutal crackdown describes what he saw | ABC NEWS
description: An Australian-Iranian dual national, whose name has been protected by the ABC for safety reasons, shared his experience protesting Iran's authoritarian regime as it began using deadly force. US-based rights group HRANA states that more than 2,600 protesters have been killed, with nearly 1,700 additional cases are under investigation.
